text.strong: ‌Do you teach any of the following subjects in <English²> in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds>?‌

text.em: (Please only consider subjects that you teach entirely or almost entirely in <English²>)
‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I teach mathematics in <English²>.
I teach <school science> in <English²>.
I teach <technology> in <English²>.
I teach <social studies> in <English²>.
I teach <arts> in <English²>.
I teach physical education in <English²>.
I teach <religion and/or ethics> in <English²>.
I teach <practical and vocational skills> in <English²>.
I teach other subjects (other than <English¹>) in <English²>.

text.strong: ‌To what extent were any of the following topics included in your professional development activities during the last 12 months?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: <English²> teaching methodology
Teaching methodology of other <foreign languages²> (different from <English²>)
Methods to teach another subject (e.g. <history, science>) in <English²>
Methods to teach another subject <history, science> in another <foreign language²> (different from <English²>)
Assessing students’ <English²> learning
Taking individual differences among <English²> students (e.g. motivation, aptitude, strategy use) into account
Using <digital resources> for <English²> teaching (e.g. online videos, websites, learning apps)
Teaching <English²> remotely (e.g. online)
Assessing <English²> skills remotely (e.g. online)
Teaching in a multicultural or multilingual setting
Communicating with people from different cultures or countries

text.strong: ‌On average, how many <national modal grade for 15-year-olds> students are there in your classroom during your <English¹> lessons this school year?‌

label.text: 10 students or fewer
11-15 students
16-20 students
21-25 students
26-30 students
31-35 students
36-40 students
41-45 students
46-50 students
More than 50 students

Assessing students’ <English²> learning
Taking individual differences among <English²> students (e.g. motivation, aptitude, strategy use) into account
Using <digital resources> for <English²> teaching (e.g. online videos, websites, learning apps)
Teaching <English²> remotely (e.g. online)
Assessing <English²> skills remotely (e.g. online)

text.strong: ‌To what extent were the following types of practical activities included in the formal <education or training> that qualified you to teach?‌

label.text: (The formal <education or training> that qualified you to teach includes all degrees and further qualifications that you needed to have in order to start teaching.)

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Observation of <English¹> lessons (e.g. in a school, in a video)
Observation of other <modern foreign language¹> lessons (apart from <English¹>) (e.g. in a school, in a video)
Observation of lessons in other subjects (e.g. <science, history>) delivered in <English²> (e.g. in a school, in a video)
Designing tasks to assess students’ <English²> learning
Designing activities to improve students’ <English²> speaking or writing skills
Designing activities to improve students’ <English²> listening or reading skills

Other <modern foreign languages¹> practice teaching in a school
<Traineeship> in a school related to <English¹> or other <modern foreign language¹> teaching

text.strong: ‌During the last 12 months, did you participate in any of the following professional development activities?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Courses/workshops (e.g. on subject matter or methods and/or other education-related topics)
Education conferences or seminars (where teachers and/or researchers present their research results and discuss educational issues)
Observation visits to other schools
Observation visits to business premises, public organisations, non-governmental organisations
In-service training courses in business premises, public organisations, non-governmental organisations

text.strong: ‌How often do the following activities happen in your <English¹> lessons in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I explain <English²> grammar rules.
I ask students to repeat <English²> words or phrases to improve their pronunciation.
I teach <English²> vocabulary.
I explain cultural aspects of interaction (e.g. being polite in <English²>, achieving appropriate levels of formality).
I show students lists of words or phrases to learn.
I ask students to listen to something and write it down word by word (dictation).
I ask students to write down some new words.
I teach students how words should be pronounced.
I teach the correct word order in <English²> sentences and questions.
I teach how to conjugate verbs (e.g. I go - she goes; go - went - gone).

text.em: ‌(<English language assistants> are assisting staff members of the staff, but not qualified teachers, who have a very good command of the <English²> language and use it in the classroom with the presence of a teacher.)‌

label.text: An <English language assistant> supports my <English¹> lessons in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds>.
Ideally, I would like an <English language assistant> to support my <English¹> lessons in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds>.

text.strong: ‌How often do the following activities happen in your <English¹> lessons in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I ask students to write something in <English²>
I play <English²>-language videos (e.g. short video clips, TV series, movies) for students
I ask students to listen to something in <English²> (e.g. songs, textbook dialogues, podcasts)
I ask students to read something in <English²>
Students speak to me in <English²>
I ask students to speak with each other in <English²>
Students speak <English²> in front of the whole class
I teach strategies to help students better understand information in <English²>
I show students how to overcome communication problems that can occur in <English²> language interactions

text.strong: ‌How often do you ask your <English¹> students in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds> to do the following activities?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

Work in groups of 3 or more students during the lesson
Do group/pair projects at home

<national adaptation 812>

text.strong: ‌How often do you organise group/pair activities for the following purposes in your <English¹> lessons in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: To improve students’ <English²> writing skills
To improve students’ <English²> speaking and listening skills
To improve students’ <English²> reading skills
To improve students’ <English²> oral interaction skills
To conduct research on a specific topic using <English²>
To help students learn about structural elements of the <English²> language (e.g. grammar, vocabulary)
To promote the use of <digital resources> as a tool for <English²> learning
To improve students’ <English²> presentation skills (e.g. presenting a topic to someone)
To teach how to conduct research using <English²>

text.strong: ‌How often do you teach the following topics in your <English¹> lessons in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: <English²>-language literature.
<English²>-language performing arts (e.g. theatre, cinema, music).
Technical <English²> (e.g. terms used in technology, commerce or the service industry).

text.strong: ‌What language(s) do the following people speak during your <English¹> lessons in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌
(Other languages include <PISA reading test language> as well as other languages different from <English²>.)

label.text: Myself (the teacher)
Students

text.strong: ‌Do you think that it is acceptable for students in the classroom to mix <English²> with another language (including <PISA reading test language>) in the same conversation?‌

label.text: Yes, and I encourage students to do this.
Yes, but I do not encourage students to do this.
No

text.strong: ‌Can you do the following things when reading in <English²>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Understand words and phrases in very short simple texts (e.g. flyers, postcards).
Understand short simple texts with predictable information and on familiar subjects (e.g. invitations, basic instructions).
Understand the main points in texts describing events and feelings (e.g. short articles, personal emails).
Understand longer texts in which the writers express their points of view (e.g. articles, reports).
Understand detailed information in longer and more complex texts related to your personal interests (e.g. books, articles).

text.strong: ‌Can you do the following things when listening to <English²>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Understand basic words, questions and expressions on familiar topics in clear very slow speech (e.g. about yourself, your family)
Understand everyday words, questions and expressions on familiar topics in clear slow speech (e.g. in short conversations about your work, hobbies)
Understand the main points of conversations, discussions and presentations in clear standard speech (e.g. in a lecture, in a TV program)
Understand the main ideas of longer and more complex conversations, discussions and presentations on familiar topics in standard speech (e.g. documentaries, interviews, films)
Understand in detail the main ideas in extended complex conversations, discussions and presentations, on familiar and unfamiliar topics in standard speech (e.g. debates, discussion programmes)

text.strong: ‌How important are the following learning goals in your <English¹> lessons in <national modal grade for 15-year-olds>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Improving linguistic knowledge (e.g. grammar, vocabulary)
Developing writing skills in <English²>
Developing reading comprehension skills in <English²>
Developing listening comprehension skills in <English²>
Developing speaking skills in <English²>
Improving knowledge of <English²>-language literature and/or performing arts (e.g. cinema, music)
Knowing about the culture of <English²>-speaking countries
Facilitating communication between individuals with no common language
Understanding the role of <English²> in international and intercultural communication
Learning to communicate in <English²> with people with limited <English²> proficiency
Improving knowledge of technical <English²> (e.g. terms used in technology, commerce or the service industry)

text.strong: ‌Can you do the following things when writing in <English²>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Write a few words and phrases about yourself (e.g. in a greeting card, a simple email or text message)
Write short descriptions about personal experiences and events (e.g. in a postcard, a short text message)
Write detailed descriptions about events, experiences and express feelings (e.g. a personal letter, journal entry)
Write your opinion on a range of topics, arguing for or against an issue (e.g. a short essay, a discussion board post)
Write clear well-structured texts on complex topics evaluating different points of view (e.g. a formal essay, a report)

text.strong: ‌Can you do the following things when speaking <English²>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: Give a short description of very familiar topics (e.g. yourself, your family)
Give a description of everyday topics (e.g. your hobbies, your work)
Give a description of events and personal experiences (e.g. about your plans, a trip you took)
Give an opinion on a current issue (e.g. on climate change, use of technology)
Summarise ideas about a complex subject (e.g. in an oral summary or presentation)

text.strong: ‌How much time do you think your <national modal grade for 15-year-olds> students need each week to study and do homework for your <English¹> lessons?‌

label.text: Less than 30 minutes a week
30 minutes to less than 1 hour a week
1 hour to less than 2 hours a week
2 hours to less than 3 hours a week
3 hours to less than 4 hours a week
4 hours or more a week

I regularly speak more than one language at home now.

During my professional training, I obtained a <degree> with <English²> as the main language of instruction.

I regularly speak <English²> with some of the people in my life (e.g. relatives, friends, colleagues, acquaintances).

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

Face-to-face communication during a stay abroad
Face-to-face communication with colleagues in my country
Face-to-face communication with other people in my country

Written communication (e.g. by mail or online chat)

label.text: Yes
No

text.strong: ‌To what extent do you use the following assessment methods in your <English¹> lessons in <national modal grade for 15-year olds>?‌

text.em: ‌(Please select one response in each row.)‌

label.text: I give students feedback on their strengths.
I tell students which areas they can improve on.
I explain to students how to avoid some grammatical errors they make.
I ask students to give feedback on each other’s work.
I ask students to evaluate their own abilities and performance.
I ask students to set their own learning goals.
I discuss with students individual action plans to improve their learning.
I ask students to reflect on their own learning processes.

label.text: Writing in <English²>
Speaking <English²>

Reading <English²>
Pronouncing <English²> in a way that can be easily understood
Knowing <English²> vocabulary
Knowing about <English²> literature and/or performing arts (e.g. cinema, music)
Knowing about the culture of <English²>-speaking countries
Improvement in <English²> during the school year
Taking previous feedback into account

label.text: I administer grammar <assignments> (e.g. quizzes or exercises).

I listen to <English²> conversations between students to assess their oral communication skills.

I evaluate students’ written or spoken answers to questions about <English²> audio/video clips they have listened to or watched.

I administer vocabulary <assignments> (e.g. quizzes or exercises).

I evaluate presentations in <English²>.
I administer reading comprehension exercises (e.g. blank filling, multiple choice questions or open-ended questions).
I administer listening comprehension exercises (e.g. blank filling, multiple choice questions or open-ended questions).
I assess student learning using material that I developed myself.
I assess student learning using material that was not developed by myself (e.g. by textbook developers, government authorities).
